Award.AwardTitle: Nuclearity, group C*-algebras and II_1 factors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary thread of research will focus on emerging analogies between the structure of II_1 factors and simple C*-algebras. For example, there are now C*-analogues of McDuff's Theorem and Connes's "Injective implies McDuff" result (which played a fundamental role in classifying injective factors). The investigator hopes to explore these analogies with the ultimate goal of classifying simple C*-algebras of so-called finite nuclear dimension. In another direction, the investigator will continue working on C*-algebras associated to groups and related spaces that were recently introduced in joint work with Erik Guentner. Finally, we will continue our study of dynamical systems associated to II_1 factors which arise from certain homomorphisms.

One very successful idea in mathematics is that we can learn about complicated objects by approximating with simpler objects, then passing to a limit. For example, in calculus we compute the area under a curve using rectangular approximations, then refining the approximations over and over. Operator algebras are (usually) infinite dimensional objects which provide the natural framework for quantum mechanics, for example. Moreover, deep and unexpected connections with other areas of mathematics such as geometry, topology and probability were discovered over the years. As such, a solid understanding of the structure of operator algebras is important. The general philosophy of using approximations by simpler objects becomes especially relevant here since the objects of interest are infinite dimensional. The investigator will continue an established tradition of trying to use finite dimensional approximations to better understand some fundamental infinite dimensional objects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported research on operator algebras, a field introduced 100 years ago as the mathematical framework for quantum mechanics. Penn State University, where the PI is a professor, has a renowned group of researchers in this area. As such, we are very active in the training of future researchers. The PI is also a committed, vocal advocate for diversity and equality in STEM fields and energetic contributor to outreach programs. 

In terms of research, this award supported work that was published in peer-reviewed journals. Several topics were studied, but the most important contribution was an 87-page proof of the Toms-Winter Conjecture for finite-dimensional Bauer simplices. This long-term, international collaboration involved researchers from Scotland, Germany and Japan. It has further solidified Penn State's reputation as an international leader in the area. 

In terms of training, the PI supervised three PhD theses during this award and used some of the monies to support their professional development (e.g. summer support for research and attending conferences and workshops). One of these students, Hung-Chang Liao, is now a postdoc at what many consider the best place in the world for his research interests (noncommutative dimension theory), Muenster, Germany. The PI also supervised Jose Carrion, an NSF postdoc, and co-authored a paper with him and Stuart White. We are happy to report Jose now has a tenure-track job at Texas Christian University where he's an important contribution to the strength and diversity of their math department. 

In terms of broader impacts, the PI gave several talks each year to local middle and high school students. It's extremely gratifying to note that several students in attendance 2-3 years ago are now math majors at Penn State. Since its inception, he has been an integral part of the Millennium Scholars Program, teaching freshman calculus each fall to this elite and diverse group of undergraduates and participating in recruitment efforts. This is arguably the highest-profile diversity-in-STEM program at Penn State, and makes an important contribution to the diversity of our nation's STEM workforce. Finally, in collaboration with Lilith Antinori, the PI started and continues to administer the website stemfeminist.com, giving voice and validation to those affected by sexism in STEM.
